query: What are the lesser-known LEGAL ways for F1 international students to earn money in the United States? Include on-campus options, CPT/OPT strategies, passive income methods, business ownership rules, and any legitimate pathways that students often overlook.

R1.A.title: On-Campus Employment Loopholes
R1.A.findings: On-campus employment is broadly defined by USCIS to include commercially operated facilities on campus (Starbucks, Barnes & Noble, etc.). Students can work 20hrs/week during school, full-time during breaks. Lesser-known jobs: simulation patient actors, esports facility workers, observatory assistants, sleep study participants.

R1.B.title: CPT/OPT Strategy Optimization
R1.B.findings: Key strategies: Day-1 CPT programs exist at some schools, part-time CPT doesn't affect OPT eligibility (full-time CPT over 12 months kills OPT), STEM OPT adds 24 months. Maximum theoretical: 6 years across two STEM degrees. Economic hardship authorization available for unforeseen circumstances.

R1.C.title: Passive Income Methods
R1.C.findings: Allowed: stock dividends, rental income (use property manager), royalties, bank interest (often tax-exempt). Gray area: YouTube/content creation - controversial, depends on activity level. Not allowed: actively selling digital products. 30% flat tax on most passive income unless treaty applies.

R1.D.title: Business Ownership Rules
R1.D.findings: F1 students CAN own LLCs/corporations but CANNOT work for them without authorization. Must be truly passive - hire others to operate. E-commerce/dropshipping is high-risk because it requires active management. OPT allows working for your own startup in your field.

R1.E.title: Non-Employment Income Streams
R1.E.findings: Clearly allowed: scholarships (unlimited), fellowships, research stipends (if no work required), competition/hackathon prizes, academic awards, crowdfunding donations, family gifts. All taxable except gifts and qualified education expenses.
